content.text: The Snow Queen. Once upon a time, there was a wicked troll—so wicked that he was the very devil himself!
One day, he made a magic mirror that had a strange power: everything good and beautiful that it reflected appeared shrunken and ugly, while everything evil and worthless looked grand and fine.
The troll and his pupils carried this mirror all over the world, laughing as they twisted the reflections of people, flowers, and even the sky.
But one day, as they tried to carry the mirror up to heaven to mock the angels, it slipped from their hands and shattered into millions of tiny fragments—some no bigger than a grain of sand.
These fragments flew far and wide, and wherever they landed, they caused mischief.
Some lodged in people’s eyes, making them see only the bad in the world.
Others settled in their hearts, turning them cold as ice.
And so, the world became a little darker, a little colder, because of the troll’s broken mirror.
A Little Boy and a Little Girl  In a large city, where the houses stood close together and the streets were narrow, lived two poor children—a boy named Kay and a girl named Gerda.
They were not brother and sister, but they loved each other as if they were.
Their families lived under the same roof, in attics so close that the rain gutters ran between their windows.
In summer, they could step from one window to the other, and in winter, they had to go all the way down the stairs and up again to visit each other.
Their favorite place was the roof, where they grew roses in wooden boxes.

The roses bloomed so beautifully that the children called their little garden "the garden of roses." They would sit among the flowers, listening to their grandmother’s stories, especially the one about the Snow Queen, who ruled over the winter winds and flew through the air in her sleigh of ice.
One winter evening, as the snowflakes danced outside, Kay and Gerda sat by the window, watching them fall.
"Look!" cried Kay. "The snowflakes are like little white bees!" Gerda laughed, but then Kay’s eyes widened. "Oh!
There’s one much bigger than the rest—it’s the Snow Queen herself!"  Gerda gasped, but before she could speak, a terrible thing happened.
A tiny shard of the troll’s mirror flew into Kay’s eye, and another lodged in his heart.
At first, he didn’t notice, but soon, everything changed.
The roses looked ugly to him, and Gerda’s stories seemed silly. "You’re just a baby," he sneered.
"I don’t want to play with you anymore."  Gerda’s heart ached, but she didn’t understand why Kay had become so cruel.
The Flower Garden of the Woman Who Knew Magic  Winter passed, and spring came, but Kay was still cold and distant.
Then, one day, as he played in the square with the other boys, a grand sleigh pulled by white horses appeared.
The driver was a tall woman in a shimmering white fur coat—the Snow Queen herself!
She smiled at Kay and beckoned him closer. "Come with me," she whispered.
"I will take you to my palace of ice, where we shall play forever."  Kay, his heart now as cold as ice, climbed into the sleigh without a backward glance.
The Snow Queen wrapped him in her fur cloak, and in an instant, they were gone, soaring over rooftops and forests, higher and higher, until the world below looked like a tiny toy.
Gerda waited for Kay to come home, but he never did.
The other children said he had been taken by the Snow Queen, but no one knew where she lived.
Gerda’s grandmother told her that the Snow Queen’s palace was far to the north, where the ice never melted.
But Gerda was determined to find Kay.
One morning, she packed a little basket with food and set off, following the river that flowed past the city.
She walked and walked, asking everyone she met if they had seen Kay.
A crow told her that a boy matching Kay’s description had been seen with a princess, but when Gerda reached the princess’s castle, she found it was not Kay at all.
Heartbroken, Gerda sat by the river and wept.
Her tears fell into the water, and suddenly, a little boat made of birch bark floated toward her.
Inside was a note: "Climb in, little girl.
The river will take you where you need to go."  Gerda stepped into the boat, and the current carried her away.
The Prince and the Princess  The river carried Gerda to a beautiful garden, where an old woman with a crooked back lived in a cottage covered in flowers.
The woman welcomed Gerda kindly and offered her berries and warm milk.
But the old woman was a sorceress who did not want Gerda to leave.
She combed Gerda’s hair with a magic comb, making her forget all about Kay.
The garden was always in bloom, and Gerda played happily among the flowers, never thinking of winter or the Snow Queen.
But one day, she saw a rose bush and remembered Kay’s garden. "Where are the roses?" she cried.
"Why are there none here?"  The old woman had hidden all the roses because they reminded Gerda of home.
But now, Gerda’s memory returned, and she knew she had to find Kay.
She ran to the garden gate, but it was locked.
The old woman had made the flowers grow so thick that they blocked the way.
Gerda knelt and prayed, and suddenly, the roses began to speak. "We will help you," they said.
"Dig beneath us, and you will find the key."  Gerda dug and found a rusty key.
She unlocked the gate and ran into the wide world once more.
Fifth Story: The Little Robber Girl  Gerda traveled through forests and over hills until she came to a dark, tangled wood.
There, she was captured by robbers and taken to their hideout, a gloomy castle filled with rough men and women.
The robber chief’s daughter, a wild and fierce girl with tangled hair, took Gerda to her room.
"You’re not going anywhere," the robber girl said, poking Gerda with a knife.
But when Gerda told her story, the girl’s heart softened. "I’ve never had a friend," she admitted.
"But if you must go, take my reindeer.
He knows the way to Lapland, where the Snow Queen’s palace is."  The reindeer knelt, and Gerda climbed onto his back.
"Thank you!" she cried, hugging the robber girl.
Then, with a bound, the reindeer leaped into the night, carrying Gerda northward.
The Lapp Woman and the Finn Woman  The reindeer carried Gerda far into the frozen north, where the snow never melted and the wind howled like a hungry wolf.
At last, they came to a tiny hut where an old Lapp woman lived.
She gave Gerda warm soup and told her that the Snow Queen’s palace was still far away.
"Go to the Finn woman," she said.
"She lives near the palace and knows more than I do."  The reindeer carried Gerda to the Finn woman’s hut, where the air was thick with steam.
The Finn woman listened to Gerda’s story and smiled.
"The Snow Queen has taken Kay to her ice palace, but he is not happy there.
His heart is still cold, but your love is stronger than her magic."  She gave Gerda a potion to keep her warm and sent her on her way.
"The palace is just beyond that mountain," she said.

"But beware—the Snow Queen’s guards are made of ice!"What Happened in the Snow Queen’s Palace and What Came of It  Gerda climbed the icy mountain and at last saw the Snow Queen’s palace—a glittering fortress of ice, with towers that sparkled like diamonds.
The wind howled around her, but she pressed on, her heart pounding. Inside, the halls were vast and silent.
At the center of the palace, on a throne of ice, sat the Snow Queen.
And there, at her feet, was Kay—frozen and still, trying to solve a puzzle of ice.
The Snow Queen had promised him that if he could spell the word "Eternity" with the ice shards, she would set him free.
Gerda ran to Kay and threw her arms around him. "Kay! It’s me, Gerda!
I’ve come to take you home!"  Kay looked at her with cold, empty eyes. "Go away," he said.
"I don’t know you."  But Gerda began to cry, and her tears fell onto Kay’s chest, melting the shard of ice in his heart.
Suddenly, Kay remembered everything. He looked at Gerda and wept. "Oh, Gerda!
I’ve been so foolish!"  The Snow Queen returned, her eyes flashing with anger. "How dare you interfere!" she hissed.
But Gerda stood firm. "You have no power over love," she said.
The Snow Queen raised her hand, but before she could strike, the ice shards around them began to melt.
The palace trembled, and the Snow Queen vanished in a swirl of snowflakes.
Kay and Gerda held each other tightly as the ice palace crumbled around them.
The reindeer found them and carried them safely home, where their families rejoiced.
Kay was himself again, and Gerda’s love had saved him.
And from that day on, whenever winter came, Kay and Gerda would sit by the window, watching the snowflakes dance, knowing that true love was stronger than any magic—even the Snow Queen’s.
The End.
